awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Medium: Towards a Usable, Practical, and Provably Secure Browser Infrastructure
awd_abstract_narration:
Web browsers have become the predominant software platform for interacting with services such as shopping, banking, and health care. Many of the same technologies that enable these applications, such as third-party JavaScript and browser extensions, also have the unintended effect of making users' private information vulnerable to theft or misuse. Existing security policies and mechanisms---such as the same origin policy (SOP), the content security policy (CSP), and permission systems for extensions---are too coarse grained and not sufficient to protect users' data. Prior work has proposed information flow control (IFC) as a solution. However, existing IFC solutions are not yet practical: they suffer from poor usability and struggle to interoperate with other enforcement mechanisms that protect parts of web applications or browser state. The goal of this project is to construct a practical, usable, and secure browser infrastructure.

The project will develop a modular model for a provably secure browser infrastructure using compositional principles.  This model will be instantiated with concrete enforcement mechanisms to develop a browser that meets the functionality standards of current browser platforms. An important part of the project is to understand users' perceptions and expectations with respect to security goals; to extract practical IFC policies based on user data; and to build mechanisms that help users safely navigate the web.  Finally, the project will develop testing and validation benchmarks and use these benchmarks to compare the effectiveness and the cost of different enforcement mechanisms. The results of this project will lay the foundation for building practical web browsers that have information flow security built in. This project targets technology that people use every day and has the potential to help not only web application developers but all web users.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The project developed a compositional model for enforcing information flow policies on web applications by leveraging browser infrastructure. This compositional information flow monitor design allows different monitoring techniques to be applied to scripts from different sources or different shared state (e.g., cookies, history, and the DOM). As a result, different compositions can explore unique tradeoffs between monitoring overhead, security guarantees, and transparency of the monitor. 

This project also explored the connections between IFC monitors and gradual type systems and built two gradual type systems, one for a high-order functional language and the other for an imperative language. These two systems showed two design choices for interpreting the dynamic (unknown) information flow label at run time: one is to decide on its concrete label mapping at memory location allocation time; the other is to gradually refine the possible label range as the program evaluates. Both systems ensure the key gradual guarantees required of gradual type systems. 

This project further incorporated statements of intended ?purpose? for a given data type (e.g., ?access location for advertising'') into information flow policies and developed hybrid monitors for enforcing these policies, making use of static analysis to reduce the instrumentation overhead of dynamic enforcement.

On the practical side, this project created an infrastructure for identifying XSS vulnerabilities in web applications by combining dynamic taint tracking with symbolic execution. This infrastructure is also capable of analyzing event handlers on the page by simulating user events. This project also created an infrastructure for conducting web-tracking studies on both desktop and mobile platforms, which won the best artifact award at PETS 2023. The study results based on a large-scale crawl using this infrastructure answered research questions about the similarities and differences between desktop and mobile tracking and the efficacy of privacy-focused mobile browsers at tracking prevention.  

Research from this project yielded new information flow monitor designs and new connections between gradual typing and information flow monitoring. The infrastructures implemented during this project allow other researchers to conduct large scale studies on XSS vulnerability detection and web tracking.

The project provided training for several undergraduates and graduate students, including several from underrepresented groups, and post-doctoral researchers. Two of the PhD students who participated in this project are scheduled to graduate by the summer of 2023.


 

 


Last Modified: 12/15/2022
Modified by: Limin Jia
